text: <@U018KDGJ2JY> has joined the channel

Anyone using GPS have any tricks for detecting dodgy sensors at the start of a (flat) race? I just got rinsed in the last at Ripon and watching back a replay of GPS render it appears that the eventual winner was miles behind the stalls at the off. Actually 8th when it won the race.... This god me thinking perhaps about applying some linear regression to the coords at offtime and pulling the strat if various outlier type conditions are not met to avoid taking a beating. Watching this replay it seems clear that the GPS sensor was maybe incorrectly calibrated as the position offset appeared constant throughout. Any suggestions for better ideas than regression? Maybe some kind of closest neighbour distance threshold? Do you chaps bother with stuff like that or just take it on the chin when there is a really dodgy sensor in the race?

elements.text: Anyone using GPS have any tricks for detecting dodgy sensors at the start of a (flat) race? I just got rinsed in the last at Ripon and watching back a replay of GPS render it appears that the eventual winner was miles behind the stalls at the off. Actually 8th when it won the race.... This god me thinking perhaps about applying some linear regression to the coords at offtime and pulling the strat if various outlier type conditions are not met to avoid taking a beating. Watching this replay it seems clear that the GPS sensor was maybe incorrectly calibrated as the position offset appeared constant throughout. Any suggestions for better ideas than regression? Maybe some kind of closest neighbour distance threshold? Do you chaps bother with stuff like that or just take it on the chin when there is a really dodgy sensor in the race?

text:
```Hi Liam, from what I can see the tracker on the winning horse had a massive GPS offset throughout the race (approx. 7 lengths by may rough calcs). 
It's one of our more senior devices and will be retired. 
Come end of this month we will be replacing our oldest kits meaning similar occurrences should become rarities.```

elements.text:
Hi Liam, from what I can see the tracker on the winning horse had a massive GPS offset throughout the race (approx. 7 lengths by may rough calcs). 
It's one of our more senior devices and will be retired. 
Come end of this month we will be replacing our oldest kits meaning similar occurrences should become rarities.

text: Well that tallies up precisely with what I observed post race.

elements.text: Well that tallies up precisely with what I observed post race.

text: Thanks Liam - how do you manage to get such fast responses?

elements.text: Thanks Liam - how do you manage to get such fast responses?

text: That's a bit worrying if I was using their feed - so basically you could lose hundreds or thousands due to them knowingly using old kit, and the response is simply "Yeah we know it was dodgy - wont happen again"

elements.text: That's a bit worrying if I was using their feed - so basically you could lose hundreds or thousands due to them knowingly using old kit, and the response is simply "Yeah we know it was dodgy - wont happen again"

text: Thats the risk you take if you decide to use it. Measurement data of any kind is rarely clean

text: Ouch...

text: That response you got was interesting though. Watching the render replays back over hundreds of races now I have seen that kind of vector offset type error. Interesting that they associate it with an old device. I would love to know more about their hardware and how it works internally.

elements.text: That response you got was interesting though. Watching the render replays back over hundreds of races now I have seen that kind of vector offset type error. Interesting that they associate it with an old device. I would love to know more about their hardware and how it works internally.

text: So I'm guessing that if the sensor was off at the start of the race in the stalls, I'm guessing could you not add a check to say if the gps readings don't map up within a certain percentage, and if your strategy is to bet in-play, then best just void the whole race just in case?

elements.text: So I'm guessing that if the sensor was off at the start of the race in the stalls, I'm guessing could you not add a check to say if the gps readings don't map up within a certain percentage, and if your strategy is to bet in-play, then best just void the whole race just in case?

text: While they are running you can spot discrepancies between price and position but before the race actually starts, it needs something more sophisticated. A race run in a straight line and you don't care about a constant offset perpendicular to the race line. Parallel  to the race like or anything with significant component in direction of race line though and you could take a beating.

elements.text: While they are running you can spot discrepancies between price and position but before the race actually starts, it needs something more sophisticated. A race run in a straight line and you don't care about a constant offset perpendicular to the race line. Parallel  to the race like or anything with significant component in direction of race line though and you could take a beating.

text: Only the shorties on the flat are ever straight though.

elements.text: Only the shorties on the flat are ever straight though.

text: Yeah I see what you saying... it's fascinating stuff!

elements.text: Yeah I see what you saying... it's fascinating stuff!

text: I would appreciate your input on something...I'm testing a strategy that uses a ML model to calculate the underlying probabilities of events; the system decides to bet when it detects value. However, I am finding that almost all bets (> 99%) are lay bets. On a typical market, I would expect inefficiencies to appear equally likely on the back/lay side; this makes me think that my model is heavily biased towards lay bets

elements.text: I would appreciate your input on something...I'm testing a strategy that uses a ML model to calculate the underlying probabilities of events; the system decides to bet when it detects value. However, I am finding that almost all bets (> 99%) are lay bets. On a typical market, I would expect inefficiencies to appear equally likely on the back/lay side; this makes me think that my model is heavily biased towards lay bets

text: Given cross matching, not really

elements.text: Given cross matching, not really

text: Sounds like you're computing the implied probability of the lay side incorrectly perhaps - how does your system determine if the lay side is value, given your forecast?

elements.text: Sounds like you're computing the implied probability of the lay side incorrectly perhaps - how does your system determine if the lay side is value, given your forecast?

text: given a forecast "true" probability of p, a value bet occurs when it is possible to lay at odds < 1/p

elements.text: given a forecast "true" probability of p, a value bet occurs when it is possible to lay at odds < 1/p

text: <@UBS7QANF3>, I'm not sure I follow, are you saying that due to cross-matching, inefficiencies are more likely to appear on the lay side? shouldn't cross-matching remove liquidity on both sides of the book?

elements.text: , I'm not sure I follow, are you saying that due to cross-matching, inefficiencies are more likely to appear on the lay side? shouldn't cross-matching remove liquidity on both sides of the book?

text: No I’m saying that I would guess price virtualisation would mean there shouldn’t be a bias towards mispricings appearing on a particular side of the market
